bibl.title: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, June 3, 1948

div1.p: Lyons returns material on loan from Hench for the Hall of Fame ceremony. She also sends copies of other material which might prove useful for Hench's book.

div1.head: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, June 3, 1948
div1.opener:
Every American is a shareholder in the Hall of Fame
HALL OF FAME : NEW YORK UNIVERSITY
I MADISON AVENUE · NEW YORK IO, N.Y.
Telephone: MURRAY HILL 3-4469
3 June, 1948.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
For the past few days I have been going
through all of the material returned to me from the printer,
as well as data received from other sources in an effort
to correlate all of the material you sent to me. I have
found everything, and you will find enclosed, first, all
of the material you sent to me under date of April 1, 1948,
with the exception of your item #13, which is the photostat
of a letter from Reed to his wife dated October 6, 1900. I
have retained this for our own files because we reproduced
this letter in the program. I have photostats of all of
the other letters which we reproduced, and which came to us
from other sources, in some instances.

Second: I am also enclosing the following, all of
which I hope will be helpful to you in the publication of
your proposed volume:
1 - A few inserts of the Wyeth reproductions of the Cornwell
painting
2 - Clear photostats of Reed's letter to General Truby,
dated December 10, 1900
3 - Lazear's microscope
4 - Paper cutter presented to Mrs. Reed by Reed
5 - Walter Reed Medal from the American Society of Tropical
Medicine
6 - A few miscellaneous photostats of letters from Reed which
I am sure you will recognize, and which probably are al-
ready in your possession. I send them merely because they
are quite clear in some respects, and there may be portions
which you may wish to reproduce in your book
7 - A good photograph of the Walter Reed General Hospital
8 - A good photographic view of the University of Virginia
9 - Pathological Building, as furnished us by the Metropolitan
Life Insurance Company
10 - Photographs of the tomb at Arlington (4 copies)
11 - Photographs of the Birthplace (2 copies)
12 - Photographs of Reed's Congressional Medal (1 large and 1 small)

In going over all of the material, I was struck
with the many, many things of interest which might have
been included in our program, but which unfortunately could
not be used for lack of space. I tried to give to the aver-
age lay person a succinct story of yellow fever, and a glimpse
of Reed's character, more particularly with regard to his
relations with his colleagues during those trying days when
he was making his experiments. Of course, physicians and
surgeons know the story of yellow fever, or should know
it (if I may say so), but I was trying to prepare a program
which would be of interest to adults and children in the
schools and colleges to whom these programs are sent for a
few years after the event. If I have failed, I should at
least be given “A” for effort.

For my own part, I have been thoroughly compensated
in working on this ceremony, first, because every short biography
I read of Reed was rather disappointing. They all seemed to
leave me with the idea that Reed tried to get all of the credit
for the extermination of yellow fever, whereas, after I became
steeped in the reading of full length biographies and other
material concerning Reed, I learned of the magnanimity of the
man.

Again, my deepest appreciation to you for all of
your aid to us in the preparation of our material. I shhall
be looking forward, with keen anticipation, to the publication
of your own volume.
div1.closer:
Cordially yours, Bertha L. Lyons
Assistant to the Director Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
